instructions:
You are a technical support assistant for Davenport Model B screw machines.

RESPONSE LENGTH:
- Simple questions: 50-100 words (6-8 bullet points max)
- Complex questions or "explain why": 150-250 words (allow more detail)
- Match response length to question complexity
- Always use bullet points, not paragraphs

CITATION FORMAT - CRITICAL:
- Include page number or timestamp when available from the source
- Format: (Source: [Type] - [Topic], page X) or (Source: Video - [Topic], timestamp MM:SS)
- Video content: cite approximate timestamp if available in the chunk
- PDF/documents: cite page number if available
- Group all sources at the end, not inline

EXAMPLE CITATIONS:
- (Sources: Troubleshooting Guide page 3, Video - Preventive Maintenance 2:15)
- (Sources: Tech Tip - Cam Roll Inspection, Engineering Bulletin #247)

SOURCE URLS:
When the knowledge base returns a blob_url or document URL, include it in this format:
- [Document Name](blob_url)
If no URL is available, just use the readable source name.

RESPONSE STYLE:
- Lead with the most likely/common cause first
- Order by probability (most common → least common)
- Be direct - shop floor workers need quick answers
- Skip background explanations unless asked
- If user asks "why" or for reasoning, explain briefly

EXAMPLE GOOD RESPONSE:
"Common causes of spindle vibration (most likely first):
1. Bar stock wrong/bent - check and replace
2. Feed fingers worn - test tension, adjust
3. Loose tooling - tighten holders
4. Bad cam rolls - lift lever, feel for flat spots
5. Machine mounting - check floor bolts

(Sources: Troubleshooting Guide page 3-5, Video - Preventive Maintenance)"

request.description: Provide this tool with a list of knowledge query intents so that the knowledge base can reason over what information should be retrieved from its knowledge sources.

tools.name: knowledge_base_retrieve
tools.description: Knowledge Base Retrieval tool to ask questions. Provide this tool with a list of knowledge query intents so that the knowledge agent can reason over what information should be retrieved from its knowledge sources. Here is a sample input - #SAMPLE INPUT START# KnowledgeAgentIntents- [\"This is intent 1\", \"This is intent 2\", \"This is intent 3\"] #SAMPLE INPUT END#.  Description of this knowledge base -   Technical knowledge base for Davenport Model B 5-Spindle Automatic Screw Machine. Contains training videos with transcripts, engineering bulletins, maintenance manuals, technical procedures, and troubleshooting guides.

output.arguments: {"request":{"knowledgeAgentIntents":["Common causes of spindle vibration on Davenport Model B","Troubleshooting steps for spindle vibration","Preventive maintenance related to spindle vibration","Cam roll inspection and cam-related vibration","Feed finger issues causing vibration","Bar stock defects and vibration","Spindle bearing wear symptoms and checks","Tooling and holder tightness procedures"]}}
output.name: knowledge_base_retrieve
output.output:
Retrieved 12 documents.Retrieved 12 documents.

【7:0†source】
Direct answer
Below are likely causes, prioritized troubleshooting steps, inspection procedures, preventive maintenance actions, and corrective actions for spindle vibration (chatter) on a Davenport Model B 5‑spindle automatic screw machine, synthesized from the available Davenport troubleshooting pages, technical tips, and training video transcripts. All items list the specific checks or actions and cite the source of that information.

1) Likely causes (in order of likelihood from the documents)
1.1 Tooling problems: wrong tool, off‑center, dull or improperly honed tool, or tool/holder not firmly mounted [ref_id:0][ref_id:0].
1.2 Machine cams / cam rolls: flat spots or damaged cam rolls/cam components that create sudden diameter/length change or vibration [ref_id:2][ref_id:6].
1.3 Feed finger / loose feed finger or pad causing poor feed and vibration [ref_id:8][ref_id:10].
1.4 Bar stock problems: wrong size/type, bent/twisted/rusty/dirty bars, or bars vibrating in stock reels/tubes [ref_id:0][ref_id:2][ref_id:7].
1.5 Incorrect feed and speed gears or incorrect cams installed on slides [ref_id:7][ref_id:0].
1.6 Machine mounting or external vibration sources (machine not secured to floor or shop vibrations) [ref_id:7][ref_id:0].
1.7 Collet grip/tension or collet not opening fully during feed stroke [ref_id:2].
1.8 Spindle bearing wear or broken/chipped parts (symptoms described in inspection checks for cam rolls, chuck levers, and bearings) — requires inspection for rolling freely, flat spots, broken levers/pins [ref_id:6][ref_id:3][ref_id:9].

2) Troubleshooting steps (actionable, numbered)
Note: follow lockout/tagout and safe machine stopping before performing checks.

Step 1 — Verify if chatter is from a single tool or all spindles
1. Make samples from each spindle to determine whether all spindles show chatter or only one position; make five workpieces, one from each spindle, and gauge them [ref_id:2][ref_id:10].

Step 2 — Quick tooling checks (most common causes)
2.1 Identify the tool that made the chatter marks if possible; if not identifiable, return to broader checks (page references) [ref_id:0][ref_id:7].
2.2 Confirm correct tool per setup document; if not, install correct tool [ref_id:0].
2.3 Check tool centering; center tool per procedure in training/lesson material [ref_id:0].
2.4 Inspect tool condition: sharpness and hone; remove, sharpen, hone properly or replace if dull or improperly honed [ref_id:0].
2.5 Ensure tool is firmly mounted in holder; remove, clean and remount, check dovetail fit and holder condition [ref_id:0].
2.6 If chatter is caused by a drill at that position, rotate the drill 90° or change the drill [ref_id:0].

Step 3 — Tool holder and slide checks
3.1 Check tool holder fastening to the slide; remove, clean and remount if loose [ref_id:0].
3.2 Verify the correct cam is installed on the slide; check documentation and install the correct cam if wrong [ref_id:0].

Step 4 — Cam roll and cam related vibration checks
4.1 Jog machine to half index (3 o’clock) on the bearing spindle opening/closing cam to inspect cam rolls and pins (disengage starting clutch before manual checks) [ref_id:6].
4.2 Manually lift cam lever and reach under cam lever to determine if the cam roll turns freely and check for flat spots; flat spots or rolls that do not turn freely indicate a cam roll or pin problem and require replacement/repair [ref_id:1][ref_id:6].
4.3 If sudden diameter/length change occurs, check the respective cam roll immediately [ref_id:6].
4.4 If cam rolls/rollers or pins are broken or have flat spots, replace roll(s) and pins and check cam components; call maintenance if parts are broken [ref_id:3][ref_id:6].

Step 5 — Feed finger and stock feed checks
5.1 While stocking, check feed finger condition and tension: use cam lever handle and move the feed lever with the feed lever roll throwout disengaged; if stock slides easily through the feed finger with little resistance, check feed finger tension and bar stock size [ref_id:8][ref_id:10].
5.2 Replace or adjust feed finger or pad if loose or worn [ref_id:8].
5.3 Check if bars are vibrating in stock reel tubes; secure stock with correct tube liners or install pusher spools if necessary [ref_id:7].

Step 6 — Bar stock and collet checks
6.1 Confirm bar stock size/type and straightness; if incorrect or bent, remove and install correct bar stock and reset collet tension [ref_id:0][ref_id:2].
6.2 Sample parts from each spindle to isolate a bad spindle, check collet grip and tension, ensure collet opens fully during feed stroke; reset collet tension or clean/replace collets/spindles as needed [ref_id:2].

Step 7 — Machine gear, mounting, and external vibration
7.1 Verify correct feed and speed gears installed; if incorrect, change them [ref_id:7].
7.2 Confirm machine is securely mounted to floor; if not, notify maintenance to secure machine [ref_id:7].
7.3 Check for external vibration sources in the shop or outside; eliminate external sources where possible [ref_id:0][ref_id:7].

Step 8 — If problem persists
8.1 After the preceding checks are Yes/OK, check for external sources of vibration within/outside the shop. If still unresolved, notify supervisor or maintenance [ref_id:0][ref_id:7].

3) Inspection procedures and observable symptoms
3.1 Cam roll / cam inspection (video procedure)
- Jog machine to half index (3 o’clock) on the cam slot, disengage starting clutch, insert cam lever handle and lift cam lever, then reach under and check that roll turns freely and has no flat spots; flat spots or non‑turning indicate faulty roll/pin [ref_id:6][ref_id:1].
- If a roll turns freely and has no flat spots, the machine can be run; if not, replace or repair and call maintenance when broken [ref_id:1][ref_id:3].

3.2 Chuck lever / pin inspection
- While stocking, open chuck and manually turn hand wheel to inspect chuck levers; a broken chuck lever will not move when pressure is applied — replace both levers if broken and call maintenance [ref_id:3].

3.3 Feed finger inspection
- With feed lever throwout disengaged, move feed lever back and forth using cam lever handle to confirm feed finger engagement and tension; stock sliding easily indicates loose fingers or incorrect stock size [ref_id:8][ref_id:10].

3.4 Workpiece sampling
- Make one workpiece from each spindle and gauge to identify whether the error is universal or isolated to a spindle [ref_id:10][ref_id:2].

4) Preventive maintenance actions (from training transcripts)
4.1 Check cam rolls and pins whenever cams are changed and after any sudden diameter or length change [ref_id:6].
4.2 During stocking, check for loose feed fingers, broken chuck levers or pins, chuck tension, and starting clutch tension [ref_id:8].
4.3 Remove chips and keep cam areas clean to avoid build‑up that may affect cam/roll operation [ref_id:6].
4.4 Replace worn feed fingers or pads and maintain proper feed finger tension [ref_id:8].

5) Corrective actions (stepwise)
5.1 Tool corrections: install correct tool, center it, sharpen/hone or replace as required, and ensure holder dovetail and clamping collar are clean and tightened [ref_id:0][ref_id:4][ref_id:0].
5.2 Cam roll / cam corrections: remove and replace cam rolls/pins with flat spots or broken parts; when removing holders (example E2763‑10) follow the half‑index removal procedure (loosen clamping collar bolt and pull holder out at half index) to service components [ref_id:6][ref_id:9].
5.3 Feed finger corrections: adjust or replace feed finger or pad; check and set correct feed finger tension [ref_id:8].
5.4 Bar stock corrections: remove incorrect or damaged bars and install correct size/type; reset collet tension and clean/replace collets as needed [ref_id:0][ref_id:2].
5.5 Mechanical/installation corrections: install correct feed/speed gears and cams, secure machine to floor, and fix any external vibration sources; call maintenance if structural or broken components are found [ref_id:7][ref_id:0].

6) Spindle bearing wear symptoms and checks (what is available in the sources)
- The retrieved content directs checking cam rolls, pins, and related components for free rotation and flat spots; while specific bearing measurement limits are not provided in the retrieved documents, symptoms of problems include rolls not turning freely, flat spots, broken pins/levers, and sudden diameter/length changes that indicate cam or related component failure [ref_id:6][ref_id:1][ref_id:3].
- For bearing/shaft removal or replacement tasks (related component work), follow the documented disassembly sequences (example: removing threading shaft without removing pulley uses ordered removal of pins, bushings, gears, spacers, thrust plate and careful drift of bearing toward belt housing) when required for deeper bearing work [ref_id:5].

7) Safety notes and warnings
- Always disengage the starting clutch and stop/jog the machine to the correct index (half index / 3 o’clock) before reaching under the cam lever or performing manual roll checks [ref_id:6][ref_id:1].
- If broken structural parts (cam rolls, pins, chuck levers) are found, call maintenance and do not run the machine [ref_id:3][ref_id:6].
- Use appropriate lockout/tagout and follow facility safety procedures before performing inspections or repairs (implied by instructions to disengage clutch and call maintenance) [ref_id:6][ref_id:3].

8) Gaps / needs for additional investigation
- The retrieved material does not include specific numeric acceptance limits for spindle bearing play, vibration amplitude tolerances, or torque/spec values for collet tension and fasteners; obtain manufacturer service manuals or engineering specifications for numeric limits and torque specs before replacing bearings or setting tolerances [ref_id:5][ref_id:4].

Sources and timestamps
- Troubleshooting flowchart — Chatter on all parts (Page 4) and follow‑ups: describes tooling checks, cam/cam‑slide checks, collet and stock checks [ref_id:0].
- Troubleshooting flowchart — Chatter on all parts when single tool cannot be identified (Page 5): feed/speed gears, machine mounting, bars vibrating in stock reel, return to page 4 and external vibration check [ref_id:7].
- Workpiece length troubleshooting and collet/stock procedures (Page 6): sampling spindles, collet grip/tension, feed/pusher checks and corrective actions [ref_id:2].
- Video training segments: cam roll and pin inspection procedure, jogging to half index and disengaging starting clutch, checking for flat spots and free rolling of cam rolls (timestamps: segment covering ~09:47–10:26 and related frames) [ref_id:6][ref_id:1].
- Video training: broken chuck lever inspection and replacement guidance (segment ~05:22–07:12) [ref_id:3].
- Technical tips / installation notes (example procedures for removing/installing parts and shaft service) for deeper disassembly tasks [ref_id:5][ref_id:4].

If you want, I can convert these into a one‑page laminated troubleshooting checklist organized by symptom and the exact sequence of steps to follow at the machine.

{
  "uid": "2ae2234d6a91_aHR0cHM6Ly9zdGo2bHc3dnN3aG5uaHcuYmxvYi5jb3JlLndpbmRvd3MubmV0L3Ryb3VibGVzaG9vdGluZy9NYXN0ZXJUYXNrJTIwVHJvdWJsZXNob290aW5nJTIwQWxnb3JpdGhtLnBkZg2_normalized_images_3",
  "blob_url": "https://stj6lw7vswhnnhw.blob.core.windows.net/troubleshooting/MasterTask%20Troubleshooting%20Algorithm.pdf",
  "snippet": "The image is a one-page troubleshooting flowchart (page 4, copyright V‑TIP, Inc. 1992) for diagnosing “chatter” that appears on all parts from all spindles. It is arranged vertically with decision diamonds/rectangles on the right and corrective-action boxes on the left, connected by Yes/No arrows.

Top:
- Start: “Chatter appears on all parts from all spindles.” (noted as coming “From page 3”)
- First decision: “Is the size or type of bar stock not correct, or is stock bent?” 
  - Yes → action: “Remove all bar stock and install the correct size and type. Reset collet tension.”
  - No → next decision: “Can you identify the tool which created the chatter marks?”
    - No → directs to “Page 5.”
    - Yes → series of sequential checks (each is a Yes/No decision with a corresponding corrective action if No):
      - “Is it the correct tool as called for in the setup document?” 
        - No → “Install correct tool as called for in setup documents.”
      - “Is the tool on center?”
        - No → “Center tool using the procedure shown in lesson.”
      - “Is the tool sharp and in good condition?”
        - No → “Remove, sharpen and/or replace the tool.”
      - “After sharpening, was the tool properly honed?”
        - No → “Remove the tool and properly hone it.”
      - “Is tool firmly mounted into the tool holder? (Check dove tail.)”
        - No → “Remove, clean and remount tool. Check holder for damage and fit of dove tail in holder.”
      - “Is the tool holder firmly secured to the slide?”
        - No → “Remove, clean and remount holder.”
      - “Is the chatter being caused by a drill at this position?”
        - Yes → action: “Rotate the drill 90° or change drill.”
      - “Is the gib on the slide properly adjusted?”
        - No → “If properly instructed, adjust gib, or notify maintenance.”
      - “Is the correct cam installed on the slide?”
        - No → “Check documentation, install correct cam.”
      - Final step if all checks are Yes: “Check for an external source of vibration within the shop or outside the shop.” If still unresolved, “Notify Supervisor if problem is not found.”

Visual notes:
- Left margin shows a boxed “4” (page number). 
- The flow uses Yes/No arrows between right-side checks and left-side corrective boxes and references other pages where appropriate."
}

```
## Segment 15: 09:49.522 => 11:00.400
The segment focuses on checking the condition of cam rolls and pins. It describes procedures for checking for broken cam lever rolls and pins, including jogging the machine to a specific position, disengaging the starting clutch, and checking if the roll turns freely and has no flat spots. The video shows close-ups of the cam rolls and the process of checking them.

Transcript
```
WEBVTT

09:47.440 --> 09:49.600
<Speaker 1>Remove the chips after sufficient draining.

09:53.280 --> 09:57.080
<Speaker 1>Check the condition of the cam rolls and pins each time the cams are changed.

09:58.080 --> 10:00.880
<Speaker 1>If a sudden diameter or length change occurs,

10:01.280 --> 10:03.360
<Speaker 1>Check the respective cam roll immediately.

10:07.840 --> 10:16.480
<Speaker 1>To check for broken cam lever rolls and pins, jog the machine to half index or 3 o'clock on the slot on the bearing spindle opening and closing cam.

10:19.040 --> 10:20.640
<Speaker 1>Disengage the starting clutch.

10:23.440 --> 10:26.080"
}

  "uid": "2ae2234d6a91_aHR0cHM6Ly9zdGo2bHc3dnN3aG5uaHcuYmxvYi5jb3JlLndpbmRvd3MubmV0L3Ryb3VibGVzaG9vdGluZy9NYXN0ZXJUYXNrJTIwVHJvdWJsZXNob290aW5nJTIwQWxnb3JpdGhtLnBkZg2_normalized_images_4",
  "blob_url": "https://stj6lw7vswhnnhw.blob.core.windows.net/troubleshooting/MasterTask%20Troubleshooting%20Algorithm.pdf",
  "snippet": "The image is a troubleshooting flowchart (page 5) titled “Chatter occurs on all parts and a single tool cannot be identified as the source.” It begins with that statement at the top, then flows downward through a sequence of yes/no checks and corrective actions:

- Check: “Are the correct Feed and Speed Gears installed?”
  - If NO → action: “Change the Feed and/or Speed gears.”
  - If YES → next check.

- Check: “Is the machine securely mounted to the floor?”
  - If NO → action: “Notify Maintenance.”
  - If YES → next check.

- Check: “Are bars vibrating in stock reel tubes?”
  - If YES → action: “Secure stock with correct tube liners and/or install pusher spools.”
  - If NO → note: “Because it is possible for the chatter vibration from a single tool to pass through the machine to other positions, return to page 4 to check for these causes.” (arrow labeled “Return to Page 4”)

- After returning/checking, the flow continues: “Check for an external source of vibration within the shop or outside the shop.”

- Final step: “Notify Supervisor if problem is not found.”

Top right corner shows copyright “V-TIP, Inc. 1992.” The page number “5” is shown in a box at the upper left."
}
【7:5†source】
{
  "uid": "2ae2234d6a91_aHR0cHM6Ly9zdGo2bHc3dnN3aG5uaHcuYmxvYi5jb3JlLndpbmRvd3MubmV0L3Ryb3VibGVzaG9vdGluZy9NYXN0ZXJUYXNrJTIwVHJvdWJsZXNob290aW5nJTIwQWxnb3JpdGhtLnBkZg2_normalized_images_5",
  "blob_url": "https://stj6lw7vswhnnhw.blob.core.windows.net/troubleshooting/MasterTask%20Troubleshooting%20Algorithm.pdf",
  "snippet": "The image is a single-page troubleshooting flowchart (page 6, Copyright V-TIP, Inc. 1992) titled essentially "The length of the workpieces is not correct." It guides a technician through a decision tree to find and fix why parts are coming out too long or too short. Key elements:

- Top: problem statement and first decision — "Are the workpieces too long?" splits the chart into two main paths (YES and NO).
- Right-side (parts too long): checks whether all parts are too long, then recommends inspecting the center tool slide cam roller or tool slide cam for flat spots, checking stock-stop adjustment, and facing-tool position. It also advises sampling parts from each spindle to identify a bad spindle, checking collet grip and tension, ensuring the collet opens fully during feed stroke, and verifying pusher movement and bar condition (bent, twisted, rusty, dirty). Recommended actions include resetting collet tension, cleaning or replacing collets/spindles, removing/cleaning/replacing bars, and replacing pushers or feed fingers as needed.
- Left-/center-side (parts produced short): checks whether all parts are produced short, then routes through stock-stop adjustment, changing stock-feed stroke (cam), and verifying feed/collet/finger sizes. Other steps include removing/sharpening/replacing dull tools, resetting end-working tools or tool-slide cams, and replacing feed fingers or collets if required.
- Final steps: if stock size is wrong, install correct bar stock; if problems persist after checks, notify supervisor or maintenance.
- Visuals: numerous decision diamonds and action rectangles arranged top-to-bottom with arrows; a small boxed page number "6" and a simple icon are at the top-left.

Overall, the chart is a systematic troubleshooting checklist to determine whether the error is mechanical (cams, collets, feed/pusher), tooling (dull or wrong tools), or stock-related, and gives directed corrective actions."
}

## Segment 10: 05:22.856 => 07:12.720
The segment continues with the process of checking for broken chuck levers during stocking maintenance. It includes engaging the starting clutch, opening the chuck, and manually turning the hand wheel to inspect the chuck lever. If a chuck lever is broken, it will not move when pressure is applied. The procedure is repeated for all five spindles. Additionally, the segment covers checking for broken chuck lever pins, ensuring the pin shows through both sides of the fulcrum. If a pin is broken, it usually falls out, and this check is also performed on all five spindles.

Transcript
```
WEBVTT

05:25.920 --> 05:27.120
<Speaker 1>Broken chuck levers.

05:28.800 --> 05:33.200
<Speaker 1>While stocking, also check for broken chuck levers on each spindle as follows.

05:35.840 --> 05:37.200
<Speaker 1>Engage the starting clutch

05:41.920 --> 05:42.800
<Speaker 1>Open the chuck.

05:46.160 --> 05:49.520
<Speaker 1>Manually turn the hand wheel so that the chuck lever is in sight.

05:52.720 --> 05:54.320
<Speaker 1>Disengage the starting clutch.

05:55.600 --> 05:58.800
<Speaker 1>With the cam lever handle, manually close the chuck.

05:59.520 --> 06:01.120
<Speaker 1>If the chuck lever is broken,

06:01.680 --> 06:07.840
<Speaker 1>The piece closest to the revolving head will not move when pressure from the cam lever handle is exerted to close the chuck.

06:09.200 --> 06:16.240
<Speaker 1>Using the same procedure, check the other chuck lever in the fulcrum that is located 180 degrees from the first one.

06:18.160 --> 06:21.600
<Speaker 1>If a chuck lever is broken, both levers must be replaced.

06:23.600 --> 06:26.240
<Speaker 1>If a chuck lever is broken, call maintenance.

06:27.920 --> 06:30.960"
}

{
  "uid": "b3f39ad3f34c_aHR0cHM6Ly9zdGo2bHc3dnN3aG5uaHcuYmxvYi5jb3JlLndpbmRvd3MubmV0L3ZpZGVvLXRyYWluaW5nL0RhdmVucG9ydCUyME1hY2hpbmUlMjBNb2RlbCUyMEIlMjAtJTIwRW5kJTIwV29ya2luZyUyMFRvb2xzLm1k0_pages_20",

  "snippet": "--> 09:39.560
<Speaker 1>Removing the E2763-10 holder, jog the machine to half index or three o'clock on the slot on the burring spindle opening and closing cam.

09:41.160 --> 09:45.240
<Speaker 1>Then disengage the stock stop latch on the rear of the first position tool spindle.

09:50.120 --> 09:55.800
<Speaker 1>Use the cam lever handle to relieve the spring tension on a latch so it can be moved out of position.

09:57.160 --> 10:01.720
<Speaker 1>This allows the spindle to move to the extreme right or low point of the cam.

10:03.400 --> 10:12.600
<Speaker 1>At half index, there is enough room between the first position tool spindle and the revolving head to remove the E2763-10 holder from the spindle.

10:15.080 --> 10:18.680
<Speaker 1>Loosen the 3/8 square head bolt in the tool spindle clamping collar.

10:22.400 --> 10:25.320
<Speaker 1>When this is loosened, the holder can be pulled out of the spindle.
```

```
04:14.960 --> 04:17.600
<Speaker 1>Preventative maintenance when stocking the Davenport.

04:20.160 --> 04:32.960
<Speaker 1>As you stock the machine, check for these problems: loose feed fingers, broken chuck levers, broken chuck lever pins, chuck tension, starting clutch tension.

04:40.560 --> 04:41.600
<Speaker 1>Loose feed fingers.

04:44.160 --> 04:49.120
<Speaker 1>While stocking each spindle, notice how the stock feeds as you push it with the stock paddle.

04:53.680 --> 05:03.200
<Speaker 1>Check for loose feed fingers on each work spindle by using the cam lever handle in the feed lever and moving it back and forth with the feed lever roll throwout disengaged.

05:08.240 --> 05:16.240
<Speaker 1>If the stock slides easily through the feed finger with little or no resistance, check the feed finger tension and bar stock for size.

05:19.280 --> 05:22.320
<Speaker 1>The feed finger or pad should be replaced or adjusted.
```

```
## Segment 9: 04:14.960 => 05:22.856
The video continues with preventive maintenance during stocking of the Davenport. It demonstrates checking for loose feed fingers on each work spindle using the cam lever handle and feed lever. The process involves moving the lever back and forth with the feed lever roll throwout disengaged. If the stock slides easily, the feed finger tension and bar stock size should be checked. The feed finger or pad may need replacement or adjustment.

Transcript
```
WEBVTT

<Speaker 1>Preventative maintenance when stocking the Davenport.

04:20.160 --> 04:32.960"

{
  "uid": "cf6062961f85_aHR0cHM6Ly9zdGo2bHc3dnN3aG5uaHcuYmxvYi5jb3JlLndpbmRvd3MubmV0L3RlY2huaWNhbC10aXBzL1RULTUwODAtMzQtMS1pbnN0YWxsYXRpb24tbG9jYXRpbmctbGV2ZXIucGRm0_normalized_images_0",
  "blob_url": "https://stj6lw7vswhnnhw.blob.core.windows.net/technical-tips/TT-5080-34-1-installation-locating-lever.pdf",
  "snippet": "The image is a single-page technical instruction sheet titled, centered at the top, "INSTALLATION OF LOCATING LEVER (5080-34-1)". Below the title is a left‑aligned, numbered step-by-step procedure (15 steps) describing how to install and fit the locating lever and its eccentric bushing. Key actions and details include:

- Inspect bushings and measure the mounting opening with a machinist’s planer gauge.
- Insert the eccentric bushing (5080-196) from the left, seat it in a vise, measure eccentric-to-flat distance and grind the eccentric .002" as required.
- Use scrapper bluing and pin (624-1) to check fit; work the lever back and forth to achieve about 90% bearing, removing high spots with a flat scraper.
- When bearing is correct, install the locating lever extension (5080-35-1) if required and simulate working mode against locating cam (5080-75-1).
- Use an indicator to check spindles, adjust eccentric until spindle 3 is less than .002", then lock eccentric with a 3/8-16 square head bolt (837-14-16).
- Drill and tap specified holes for pins and screws (details include a .248 (D) ~3/4" deep hole for a .250 soft pin, taps for 1/4-24 and 7/16-14, and a through-drill/tap to 3/8-16).
- Remove screws and burrs, ensure pin is flush, reinstall lever and set roll pressure per the instruction book.

Two safety/attention notes are emphasized in the text: "Use care, as lever may be tight." and "Take care as not to loosen wedge." The page contains numerous part numbers and specific drill/tap sizes for precision machining."
}
【7:11†source】
{
  "uid": "e4c41c42a1d5_aHR0cHM6Ly9zdGo2bHc3dnN3aG5uaHcuYmxvYi5jb3JlLndpbmRvd3MubmV0L3RlY2huaWNhbC10aXBzL1RULXJlbW92aW5nLXRocmVhZGluZy13aXRob3V0LXB1bGxleS5wZGY1_pages_0",
  "blob_url": "https://stj6lw7vswhnnhw.blob.core.windows.net/technical-tips/TT-removing-threading-without-pulley.pdf",
  "snippet": "If for any reason you need to remove your threading shaft from your machine,
it’s possible to do without removing it through the belt housing. This can be

done by following the steps listed below.

REMOVE the following:

1) 5080-239 Taper Pins (there will be 2)

2) 5080-226-15 Threading Shaft Bushing (long "T" shaped bushing on cam lever end)

3) Threading shaft drive gear 

4) 5080-226-5-2 Intermediate Stem Collar (slide toward threading clutch)

5) MB-227 Thrust Plate (slide toward threading clutch)

6) MB-228, MB-229 Spacers (slide toward threading clutch)

7) Slide threading shaft towards the belt housing and using a brass or aluminum drift punch,

carefully drive the bearing out towards the belt housing

8) Remove the four (4) screws in the high and low pressure gauges and carefully move the two

(2) gauges down

9) Slide all loose components off the end of the shaft

10) Slide the shaft out between the belt housing just above the wire carrier (stock reel)

To install the shaft simply reverse the process listed above. Be sure to install the MB-227 Thrust Plate
and bearing inner race before installing the shaft.

When reinstalling the needle bearing be sure none of the needles have come out or lost and that the
bearing is in enough to be able to slide in the thrust plate.

Another 100 Years
Another 100 Years

Removing and Reinstalling Threading
without Removing the Pulley

content.text:
Most likely causes of spindle vibration (most likely first):
- Tooling problems: off‑center, dull/improper hone, wrong tool, or loose in holder
- Cam / cam roll issues: flat spots, seized or loose cam rolls/pins
- Feed fingers / pads: loose, worn, or incorrect tension/size
- Bar stock: bent, wrong size/type, or vibrating in stock tubes
- Incorrect feed/speed gears or wrong cams installed on slides
- Machine mounting or external shop vibration
- Collet grip/tension or worn collets
- Spindle/bearing wear or broken/chipped parts

Stepwise troubleshooting (quick checks first):
1. Make 5 sample parts (one per spindle) to see if chatter is on one spindle or all (isolate problem)  
2. Inspect tooling: verify correct tool, center it, sharpen/hone or replace, and firmly remount holder/dovetail  
3. Check tool holder/slide: tighten clamping collar, verify gib adjustment and correct cam on slide  
4. Inspect cam rolls/pins: jog to half‑index, disengage starting clutch, lift cam lever and feel roll for free rotation/flat spots (replace if faulty)  
5. Check feed fingers while stocking: move feed lever with throwout disengaged—adjust/replace if stock slides too easily  
6. Verify bar stock: correct size/straightness, secure in tubes/pusher spools to stop vibration  
7. Confirm feed/speed gears and machine mounting; eliminate external vibration sources  
8. If still unresolved, check collet tension/condition and call maintenance for bearings or broken structural parts

Safety note:
- Disengage starting clutch, lockout/tagout and call maintenance if you find broken cam rolls, pins, or chuck levers

Sources:
- [MasterTask Troubleshooting Algorithm.pdf](https://stj6lw7vswhnnhw.blob.core.windows.net/troubleshooting/MasterTask%20Troubleshooting%20Algorithm.pdf) (Sources: Troubleshooting Guide pages 4–6, Video - Preventive Maintenance 10:19–10:26; 04:14–05:22; End Working Tools 09:41–10:12)
